title: 106_s2748
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, leased for $100-300 million annually. The facility covers a 28 square-mile area with over 1,500 Russian personnel. The Lourdes facility in Cuba is operated by the Russian Federation with over 1,500 personnel. It has tracking dishes and a satellite system for intercepting communications. The facility has been used to gather sensitive information about US military operations and collect personal information on US citizens for cyberwarfare. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, operated by the Russian Federation, has grown in operational significance since 1996. The Russian government has reportedly spent over $3 billion on its operation and modernization. Former US officials confirm the facility's expansion, with high-ranking Russian military delegations visiting Cuba to discuss its continued operation. Prohibition on bilateral debt rescheduling and forgiveness for the Russian Federation. Prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian Federation's debt to the US until the closure of the intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba. President can waive this if deemed necessary for national interest. The President can waive the prohibition on rescheduling or forgiving Russian Federation's debt to the US if deemed necessary for national interest. The President must provide a detailed description of the reasons for the waiver and may submit the certification in classified form if appropriate. Every 180 days, a report must be sent to the House of Representatives and the Senate on the extent to which the requirements are being met. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must submit a report every 120 days detailing Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility in Cuba and efforts by US agencies to verify these actions.
